etymologies: mid 18th century: from French élite ‘selection, choice’, from élire ‘to elect’, from a variant of Latin eligere (see elect). elite (sense 2) dates from the early 20th century

definitions: a select group that is superior in terms of ability or qualities to the rest of a group or society

examples.text: the elite of Britain's armed forces

shortDefinitions: select group that is superior to the rest of group

definitions: a group or class of people seen as having the greatest power and influence within a society, especially because of their wealth or privilege

examples.text: the silent majority were looked down upon by the liberal elite

shortDefinitions: small group seen as having the most power on account of their wealth or privilege

definitions: a size of letter in typewriting, with 12 characters to the inch (about 4.7 to the centimeter).
shortDefinitions: size of letter in typewriting, with 12 characters to inch
